author: dragan2836472
content:
This is my understanding: if the marker is set at the 129th bit and the value never gets deleted from a verkle tree how could the whole v⁽ˡᵒʷᵉʳ ᵐᵒᵈⁱᶠⁱᵉᵈ⁾ᵢ be set to 0, that means we delete it?

For example:

never been accessed:
v⁽ˡᵒʷᵉʳ ᵐᵒᵈⁱᶠⁱᵉᵈ⁾ᵢ = "0b010101...(128 bits)...0" -> last zero is 129th bit (and the rest of bits from 130..256 are also zeros)-> the marker

accessed:
v⁽ˡᵒʷᵉʳ ᵐᵒᵈⁱᶠⁱᵉᵈ⁾ᵢ = "0b010101...(128 bits)...1" -> last 1 is 129th bit (and the rest of bits from 130..256 zeros)-> the marker

author: jsign
content:
> how could the whole v⁽ˡᵒʷᵉʳ ᵐᵒᵈⁱᶠⁱᵉᵈ⁾ᵢ be set to 0
It's because the default value is zero. You don't actually "set" that case, it's the default value (i.e: never touched).
The first time you touch that value, you set the marker bit forever... so no matter what future values you set there (i.e: even zero) you can always detect that this value was touched.

(Small note reg your example: the bits should be counted from the least significant bit to the most significant bit)
